1.text: Harvest rosemary in the spring or summer if you want it to grow back.

2.text: Snip off rosemary stems at the base using sharp garden shears or scissors.

3.text: Cut up to 1/3 of the stems off a rosemary plant at one time.

4.text: Take smaller, younger stems from rosemary plants for the freshest taste.

5.text: Freeze or dry unused fresh rosemary to preserve it.

6.text: Rinse fresh rosemary under cool running water.

7.text: Use paper towels or a salad spinner to dry the rosemary.

8.text: Run your fingers along a stem of rosemary to strip the leaves off.

9.text: Place fresh rosemary leaves onto a cutting board.

10.text: Arrange the leaves into a neat pile with all the tips going in the same direction.

11.text: Use a chef’s knife to slice one way across the leaves to chop the rosemary.

12.text: Slice the leaves again, going the other way across the pile, to mince the rosemary.

13.text: Snip the rosemary leaves up using sharp kitchen scissors as an alternative.
